thread.section_title: Finance | Business and Finance News | News.com.au
thread.title: Finance news you need to know today
thread.title_full: Finance news you need to know today

title: Finance news you need to know today
text:
HERE are eight things making news in business and finance around the world today.
1. SYDNEY — The Australian dollar has edged higher after global markets stabilised overnight and China’s stock market closed less than half a per cent lower ahead of a national holiday. At 0630 AEST on Thursday, the currency was trading at 70.31 US cents, up from 70.24 cents on Wednesday.
2. SYDNEY — And the Australian share market looks set to open higher after Wall Street rose with investors piling back into blue chips and tech stocks as a Federal Reserve report depicted steady US economic growth. At 0645 AEST on Thursday, the September share price index futures contract was up 35 points at 5,085.
3. WASHINGTON — The US economy has stuck to its modest pace in recent months but companies have complained that China’s slowdown and the strong dollar are hurting business.
4. WASHINGTON — New orders for US manufactured goods edged higher in July after a solid increase in June, led by gains for boats and ships, the Commerce Department says.
5. WASHINGTON — The US private sector saw a slight bump in job growth in August, keeping in line with the year’s trend in an improving labour market, payroll firm ADP says.
6. JAKARTA — International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde says Asian economies are doing “pretty well” despite the volatility created by China’s slowdown and unease on global financial markets.
7. LONDON — The European Commission has given its approval for Royal Dutch Shell’s planned acquisition of Britain’s BG Group in a deal that must also be cleared by Australian and Chinese regulators.
8. COPENHAGEN — The world’s largest toy maker Lego has reported a jump in first half profit and sales, underpinned by strong growth in Asia. Lego leapfrogged over Mattel, maker of Barbie dolls, whose sales slipped to $US1.9 billion in the six months ended June 30 from $US2 billion last year.
